channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: North Korea Fires Test Missiles, Defying U.N. Ban
item.description: The two projectiles, believed to be Scud-C missiles, flew about 310 miles and crashed into the sea off North Korea’s east coast, a South Korean statement said.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Brazil Adjusts Guidelines for Diagnosing Defect Linked to Zika
item.description: Officials adopted stricter guidelines to determine when babies have been born with abnormally small heads, a step expected to reduce the number of false positives for microcephaly.
item.dc:creator: VINOD SREEHARSHA

item.title: World Briefing: Peru: Candidate Barred From Race
item.description: Peru’s electoral council on Wednesday blocked the candidacy of the main challenger to the front-runner, Keiko Fujimori, in the April 10 presidential elections.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Germany: Suspects in Cologne Attacks Are Found
item.description: The police announced the detention of two men suspected in some of the more than 1,000 assaults reported in Cologne on New Year’s Eve.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Zika Vaccine Still Years Away, W.H.O. Says
item.description: Despite efforts to speed up development, a vaccine to combat the virus may come too late for the current outbreak in Latin America and the Caribbean, health experts said.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fumigating a home for the mosquito that carries the Zika virus in Recife, Brazil, last month.

item.title: Ex-President of Brazil, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, Faces Charges
item.description: The specific charges filed on Wednesday were unclear, but they were connected to claims of money laundering and misrepresentation of assets involving a luxury apartment.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: Former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil in Brasilia on Wednesday.

item.title: ISIS Detainee’s Information Led to 2 U.S. Airstrikes, Officials Say
item.description: The prisoner is an Iraqi chemical weapons specialist who provided details about the Islamic State’s cache to military interrogators, Pentagon officials said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:credit: Kurdistan Regional Security Council, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An American and Iraqi special operation team on a raid last fall. Raids like that led to the capture of Sleiman Daoud al-Afari, a chemical weapons expert for the Islamic State.

item.title: Sinosphere: China’s Harsh Child Discipline, Through the Lens of Domestic Violence
item.description: The continued use of corporal punishment by Chinese parents has stoked new debate in light of a recent law against abuse within the family.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Elementary students in Fuzhou, China. The country outlawed corporal punishment in schools in 1986.

item.title: Biden Condemns Palestinian Violence in Implicit Rebuke to Abbas
item.description: During his visit to Israel, the vice president responded to recent attacks, including one on Tuesday that killed an American student.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Master of Go Board Game Is Walloped by Google Computer Program
item.description: The match between Google DeepMind’s AlphaGo and Lee Se-dol was seen as a test of how far research into artificial intelligence has come.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN and JOHN MARKOFF

item.title: Polish Court Strikes Down Law Limiting Its Powers, Inflaming a Crisis
item.description: The right-wing government of Poland said it would ignore a ruling by the Constitutional Tribunal, the only court empowered to review national laws.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT
item.media:description: The Constitutional Tribunal of Poland held a hearing on Tuesday in Warsaw.

item.title: Awash in Empty Homes, China Asks Migrant Workers to Settle Down
item.description: Beijing hopes to turns the country’s hundreds of millions of itinerant laborers into homeowners as the slumping property market drags on the economy.
item.dc:creator: OWEN GUO
item.media:description: Wuhan, in Hubei Province in central China, in August. The housing glut is one of the biggest drags on China’s economy, which makes it one of the major drags on global growth.

item.title: Cologne Police Detain 2 Suspects in New Year’s Eve Attacks
item.description: A 26-year-old Algerian and a 31-year-old Iraqi were detained in the investigation into hundreds of sex attacks and robberies on Dec. 31 in the German city.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:credit: Cologne Police, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: An image of a suspect wanted in connection with the assaults on women in Cologne, Germany, on New Year’s Eve.

item.title: Protesters in France Take to Streets Over Proposed Changes to Labor Law
item.description: Thousands marched in Paris on Wednesday to protest proposals that would make it easier to fire workers, but that the government says could mean more jobs.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: A protest against proposed labor law overhauls near the Place de la République in Paris on Wednesday.

item.title: Balkan Nations Shut Down March of Migrants
item.description: Since Tuesday, countries in southeastern Europe have moved to close the migrant trail, even as the European Union continues talks with Turkey.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.media:description: Migrants lined up for food at a makeshift camp at the Greek-Macedonian border, near the Greek village of Idomeni, on Wednesday.

item.title: 19 Shabab Fighters Die in Somalia in Strike Aided by U.S.
item.description: The commando attack occurred at a village 40 miles west of Mogadishu on Tuesday night, with the help of American military advisers and helicopters.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MOHAMMED IBRAHIM
item.media:description: The aftermath of a car bombing in Mogadishu, Somalia, on Wednesday, that killed at least four people, including three police officers.

item.title: Germany’s Embrace of Migrants Spawns Rise of Far-Right Leader
item.description: Frauke Petry, a brisk, garrulous leader of the Alternative for Germany party, is riding a tide of angry populism and finding success at the polls.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Frauke Petry, chairwoman of the right-wing Alternative for Germany party, at a rally in Bitterfeld last week for the Saxony-Anhalt state elections. The state is one of three voting on Sunday.

item.title: Trilobites: Views of the Total Solar Eclipse
item.description: Thousands across the world watched the eclipse on Wednesday, with many capturing captivating images.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS ST. FLEUR
item.media:description: Dancers perform during the total solar eclipse in Matantimali, Central Sulawesi, which is an island of Indonesia.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: ‘Alarm Will Sound’: Chappatte on Brexit
item.description: Getting out of the European Union might be tougher than it seems.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK CHAPPATTE

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Enduring Curse of Caste
item.description: Instead of withering away as Indian democracy matures, social discrimination has asserted itself in new ways.
item.dc:creator: ANANYA VAJPEYI
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dalits, or untouchables, traditionally sweep trash and clean overflowing sewage from roadsides in India.
